did.head: Collection Overview
did.abstract: Journalist and war correspondent. Papers relate primarily to her professional life, including teaching and her career as journalist. Includes coverage of the Second Quebec Conference and political conventions; World War II and its aftermath; the Berlin Airlift; the Korean War; China and the UN; Dag Hammarskjold; war in the Congo; Cuban Missile Crisis; Adlai Stevenson's trip to Latin America; the Vietnam War; and the 1976 presidential debates. Material includes writings, broadcast scripts, speeches, disc recordings, films, correspondence, diaries, photographs and audio tapes.

chronitem.event: Born on 13 February in Gallitzen, Pennsylvania
Graduated from Central High School, Harrisburg, Pennsylvania
Graduated from American University, major in political
Received M.A. in international law from American University
Wrote newspaper columns and reported freelance (U.S. News, North American Newspaper Alliance, Uncle Sam's Diary.
Taught at Fairmont Junior College, Washington, DC
Worked as editorial and radio assistant to H.R. Baukhage,commentator for ABC and NBC
Toured China and Burma, May to August

eventgrp.event: Served as war correspondent for North American Newspaper Alliance, Western Newspaper Union, and H.R. Baukhage
Covered Europe and the Nuremberg trials

chronitem.event: Joined NBC in June as UN correspondent
Received the Alfred I. duPont Award
Elected president of the United Nations Correspondents Association
Published Ten First Ladies of the World
Joined National Public Radio as foreign affairs analyst

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection

daodesc.p:
Pauline Frederick at the races,
Warsaw, Poland, 1949

scopecontent.p: The Pauline Frederick Papers consist of 33 linear feet of correspondence, writings, printed material, broadcast scripts, broadcast and press conference transcripts, notes, writings, speeches, photographs, memorabilia, and audiovisual materials. The inclusive dates are c. 1908 to 1990, but most of the material dates from 1932 to 1980, essentially from her extremely productive professional years. The personal material consists of correspondence, diaries, scrapbooks, and early school material.
Film and audio recordings from this collection have been digitized and are available to view online (Smith campus access only).

arrangement.head: Organization of the Collection
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into six series:

odd.head: Appendix: Alphabetical list of Photographs of Individuals
odd.p: Photographs of the following individuals are included in the Frederick Papers in Series IV. PHOTOGRAPHS under the subseries "Professional Activities," within the folders indicated here.

accessrestrict.p: The papers are open to research according to the regulations of the Sophia Smith Collection without any additional restrictions.

userestrict.p: The Sophia Smith Collection owns copyright to unpublished works of Pauline Frederick. Copyright to materials created by others may be owned by those individuals or their heirs or assigns. It is the responsibility of the researcher to identify and satisfy the holders of all copyrights. Permission must be obtained from the Sophia Smith Collection to publish reproductions or quotations beyond "fair use."

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please use the following format when citing materials from this collection:
Pauline Frederick Papers, Sophia Smith Collection, Smith College, Northampton, Mass.

altformavail.head: Additional Formats
altformavail.p: Film and audio recordings from this collection have been digitized and are available to view online (Smith campus access only).

acqinfo.p: Pauline Frederick Robbins donated her papers in four installments between 1985 and 1987.

processinfo.p: Processed by Amy Hague and Susan Boone, 1993.

scopecontent.p: The first six subseries, from Fairmont Junior College through National Public Radio, follow Frederick's career from 1931 to 1980. There are some examinations and printed material from her year teaching at Fairmont Junior College in 1933-34. Her work as assistant to H.R. Baukhage is represented by notes from her coverage of the second Quebec Conference in 1944; programs, notes, and memorabilia from the national political conventions in 1944; one script from 1941; and miscellaneous correspondence, 1938-40. The War Correspondent subseries dates from 1945 to 1946, when she was working free-lance for the North American Newspaper Alliance, the Western Newspaper Union, and H.R. Baukhage. It contains correspondence, articles, reports, memorabilia, and clippings from Frederick's China/Burma trip, her work in Europe, and the Nuremberg trials. The ABC, NBC, and National Public Radio subseries contain correspondence, broadcast scripts and transcripts, interviews, notes, UN documents, and memorabilia related to her work for these networks between 1946 and 1980. These subseries concern programs and special events, press conferences, official tours, contract and inter-office business, publicity, and specific subjects. Among the many events covered during these years were the Berlin Airlift, the Korean War, China and the UN, Dag Hammarskjold, the Congo war, the Cuban missile crisis, Adlai Stevenson's trip to Latin America, and the Vietnam War. Of special interest in these sections, are Frederick's original broadcasts and interviews, the subject sections, and NBC correspondence and reports to William McAndrew (her boss.)

The Other Activities subseries consists of correspondence, scripts, printed material, publicity, meeting agendas, and notes related to various organizations in which Frederick was involved from 1942 to 1984. There is substantial material from her term as president of the United Nations Correspondents Association in 1959.
The Speeches and Events subseries contains the texts, related correspondence, publicity, and itineraries for her busy lecture schedule, 1931-85.

The Writings subseries reflects Frederick's career as a writer and columnist. It contains typescripts, clippings, printed articles, notes, and correspondence. These materials relate to her newspaper columns "Women in Official Life" (1932) and "Women of Diplomacy" (1932), various articles she wrote from the 1930s to the 1980s (particularly for the North American Newspaper Alliance and U.S. News in the 1930s), portions of a book to which she contributed (published in 1941 as America Prepares for Tomorrow), and Ten First Ladies of the World, which she wrote and published in 1967. The texts of reports Frederick wrote as a war correspondent are located in this subseries.

Frederick's professional correspondence consists of letters from fans and listeners, invitations, correspondence with notable persons, and letters related to specific subjects. Those from fans and listeners are of particular interest because they contain comments (both of praise and criticism) on specific interviews and programs as well as general letters from her wide and appreciative audience. The personal correspondence is with friends and family. Of particular interest are the letters from Frederick to her long-time friend Ann Cordell (1950-1963) and the early letters to her sister, Catharine Crowding (1941-1946), which contain detailed descriptions of her experience overseas. The business correspondence contains her sister's letters concerning Frederick's business affairs during the period 1945 to 1946 and a group of miscellaneous business-related papers.

The Articles and Clippings date from 1948 to 1984 and are a miscellaneous group of materials about Frederick. The early diaries (1940s, 1950s) are incomplete, but are detailed for the short time spans that they cover. The diaries dating from 1968 to 1984 are appointment calendars used as diaries. The School and College material dates from 1917 and consists of school compositions, clippings, memorabilia, grade reports, and writings from grammar school, junior high school, high school, and college. Her master's thesis from American University is included in this subseries. The Awards and Honorary Degrees subseries consists of correspondence, publicity, and printed material related to the many awards Frederick received between 1950 and 1985.

This series contains approximately 4200 photographs, the majority of which relate to Pauline Frederick's professional activities, and include many of her colleagues, and the officials and celebrities with whom she came into contact during her long career. The bulk of these are from World War II on--there are few from her earliest professional years. There is also a smaller number of photographs of her personal activities, including childhood, school, family, and vacation pictures.

There are approximately 90 sound recordings (divided into three subseries, Phonograph Records, Cassette Tapes, and Reel-to-reel Tapes) which for the most part selectively document Frederick's radio and television broadcasting career, primarily during the ABC through NPR years. Others are of speeches, award programs, and other professional events. There are also tapes of interviews of Frederick by others and of her 1969 wedding. Most of the cassettes are duplicates of the reel-to-reel tapes, copied for research use but there are a few unique tapes in both categories. The Films subseries contains 8 reels of film (16, 8, and 35 mm.) of miscellaneous broadcasts, interviews, and events.
This series consists of a small number of posters, awards, honorary degrees, and photographs that have been separated from like materials because of their size.
